Award.AwardTitle: Female Sociality, Dispersal, and Comparative Microbial Community Composition in Pan troglodytes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research focused on the exceptional degree of sociality characterizing the human species and many of the other primates has demonstrated clear, adaptive benefits to strong social bonds. These positive benefits include increased health, longevity, and reproductive success, as well as associated reductions in stress, increased resilience, and enhanced social learning. Such multiple and critically important benefits of strong social relationships suggest that there are evolved mechanisms underlying these adaptive consequences. Deciphering the core aspects of developmental origins and the mechanisms accounting for persistence of bonds throughout the lifetime of highly social females, however, is difficult in the complex, multilayered societies found in exceptionally long-lived species such as our own. This research therefore will examine the developmental and longitudinal aspects of female social bonds in a primate model, that of wild chimpanzees, the closest living relatives of humans. These primates also are long-lived, transient during their lifetimes, and characterized by complexly structured societies and relationships, with females developing strong affiliative and preferential bonds in their natal communities, before emigrating to new communities as adults and forming social relationships in this context. Utilizing a unique research design employing microbiome signatures indicative of female movements between their natal and adult communities, as well as genetic, behavioral, and hormonal data related to social bonding, the project will circumvent research limitations for such highly social females and permit addressing hypotheses relevant to understanding the relationships between social bonds, health and well-being.

This interdisciplinary, collaborative research applies distinctly transformative microbiome and autosomal genotype-based analyses with behavioral and endocrinological studies to explain patterns of female immigration and the basis for, benefits of, and persistence of female bonds through their lifespan. Specifically, this study will conduct next generation, direct-DNA microbial and autosomal sequencing of over 1000 wild female chimpanzees to determine natal community origins, immigration patterns, and longitudinal perspectives of female sociality and relationships. To test the hypothesis that female social relationships are adaptive, the research will apply hormone analyses (cortisol, a stress marker, and oxytocin, a marker for bonding) to a subset of habituated females. This natural laboratory permits examination of the relationships between microbial variation and host genetics, biogeography, and relatedness (kinship), which will contribute to understanding the factors driving social relationships, host-microbial diversity, and associated health consequences.

The expansive and diverse datasets generated through the research will be broadly disseminated, facilitating future research in multiple scientific areas. Associated training and collaboration will focus on both US and international collaborators and students, thereby enhancing research capacity. And as the wild primates serving as the model study species are critically endangered, the microbiome and dispersal patterns data will find application in promoting the health of the species and informing conservation policy, particularly in increasingly fragmented habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes addressing the intellectual merits of this study include using novel, microbiome-and genotype-based methods to examine group composition and patterns of female dispersal among a multitude of wild chimpanzee communities in Uganda. Few life history studies have been conducted on females in wild populations, though their importance is paramount. Distributions of animals across habitats and time may appear random, yet larger scale analyses can reveal underlying patterns. Understanding these patterns of distribution is a core goal of socio-ecology and necessary for understanding individual behavior, social systems, and implementing sound conservation policies. 

Outcomes from this research have been and continue to be disseminated via multiple presentations and publications, including an edited volume on the primate microbiome. We are also integrating these interdisciplinary research and methods into our undergraduate classes, seminars, and graduate training to increase cross-disciplinary training in primate behavior, biology, and evolution. 

The Broader Impacts of this research include integrating microbiology, genetics, endocrinology and behavioral data and strengthening the interdisciplinary foundations of chimpanzee research.This research supported the training of several female and underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students and several Ugandan research assistants and collaborators. This project also has clear conservation implications, by supporting a team of snare removers patrolling throughout Kibale National Park, collecting fecal samples, and removing illegal hunting snares that chimpanzees frequently encounter. Moreover, the chimpanzee microbiome provides novel insights into community health and environmental influences. Understanding chimpanzee grouping and female dispersal patterns is relevant to current conservation policy in Uganda, particularly when formulating policy regarding areas for increased protection, fragmented habitats, and planning wildlife corridors. 

Key outcomes from this research include the collection, sequencing, and analysis of more than 3100 fecal samples from both habituated and unhabituated wild chimpanzees throughout Kibale National Park, Uganda. Samples were obtained from chimpanzees in all areas of the park. We genotyped 13 chimpanzee autosomal microsatellites and applied 16S rDNA Illumina tag libraries of gut microbes to define and characterize host microbial community composition. We also were able to shotgun sequence a subset of these samples. This dataset far exceeded (>3X) our proposed expectations of the number and diversity of samples that we hoped to collect and analyze for this study, resulting in a large, diverse and invaluable set of sequence data containing both genomic and microbial data of wild chimpanzees from Kibale National Park, Uganda that will be an invaluable resource for myriad future studies. 

From this extensive dataset of samples, we have made progress toward accurately estimating wild chimpanzee population and community sizes. This was accomplished by building networks of community membership and locations based on where individuals were sampled over time and which individuals were in association at the time of sampling. From these data, we determined the locations and population size of thirteen wild chimpanzee communities within the National Park and then used genetic capture recapture estimates (which model population size based on the number of recaptures of the same individual vs the number of captures of unique individuals) to estimate community sizes. Our findings indicate that the median community size is 97 individuals, which is notably more than twice the median size of our small sample of known, habituated chimpanzee communities. We have shared our knowledge of the size and locations of unhabituated chimpanzee communities in Kibale with the Uganda Wildlife Authority, who have been trying to habituate another chimpanzee group for eco-tourism. Our results showed that they have in fact actually been attempting to habituate two distinct communities. As a result of our genetics work, they now know where to concentrate their habituation efforts.  Novel genetic and microbial insights also led us to document fifteen cases of female dispersal between communities. Patterns of dispersal indicated that females generally moved between adjacent communities, although some females did disperse farther (up to 20 km2 away).

In addition to inroads into ongoing analyses of female dispersal and chimpanzee community diversity, these data help to explain factors affecting variation in microbiome community composition, and have contributed to methodological advances, including the effect of different sequencing platforms (Miseq vs Hiseq 2500) and the reproducibility of DNA extraction and sequencing events. Along with these key outcomes, our methodology quality control tests also indicate that differences in fecal sample storage (ethanol vs rnalater) lead to variation in microbiome profiles. These findings also indicate that these differences in microbial composition resulting from storage differences are relative and that their significance depends on the level of comparison (i.e. the extent of variation between groups), thus paving the way for the broader use of comparative samples. This project also has been instrumental in developing data visualization methods to provide greater clarity regarding inter-individual microbial differences, which is highly relevant for understanding microbial diversity, interactions between wild chimpanzee communities, and microbial transmission pathways.
